question: Shep! Shep, are you all right?
answer: Can't make it, Cary. Can't make it.

question: Here, give me your arm! I'll get you out of here! Hang on there, Shep! Get a hold - Just hold tight, old fella. Well, the old guerre is finie.
answer: That's right.

question: What are ya gonna do now, Shep?
answer: Get tight.

question: And then what?
answer: Stay tight.

question: Stay tight.
answer: Lieutenants Lambert and Lockwood. You two leaving us, eh? In a way, I'm sorry to release you two. I have no choice in the matter.

question: What am I going to do, Major, about my-- oh, this rotten business?
answer: Mm? Spasmodic twitching of the muscles under the eye, eh, Lieutenant?

question: Mm hm.
answer: What the French call a tic. T-I-C, tic. Little bothersome, isn't it?

question: Yes, sir.
answer: I'm afraid time'll have to take care of that. Time and normal living. You two are returning to the United States, I presume?

question: I'm afraid time'll have to take care of that. Time and normal living. You two are returning to the United States, I presume?
answer: Ah, we haven't decided.

question: I'd take the first boat home. Well, here you go. Oh, I forgot your burnt hands. Neither of you is fully hospitalized. I'd undertake a systematic course of finger exercises -- to, uh, stretch them and loosen them up. In time, you'll regain their full use.
answer: Thank you, sir.

question: Oh, the man came and got his teeth.
answer: Well, what did he say?

question: He said thank you for holding his teeth.
answer: What did he look like?

question: I think he fell in an airplane in the war -- and got his teeth knocked out.
answer: Well, why do you think he was in the war?

question: Oh, he had a kind of little striped ribbon in his buttonhole.
answer: What makes you think he was a flyer?

question: His eyes.
answer: His eyes? You can tell a flyer better by his ears.

question: Oh, my, my!
answer: Poor sweet! She can't even hold her glass!

question: Oh, well, HE can't either. Besides, he has to use two hands.
answer: Course he can't hold his glass. His hands are burned.

question: Burned?
answer: You have no right to spill YOUR drinks. He can't help himself.

question: Burned? How burned?
answer: He brought a plane down on fire.

question: An airplane? In the war?
answer: He held the stick. But his hands began to slip. Then he held it inside his arms. He was trying to bring his rear gunner down alive.

question: Did he bring him down safe?
answer: Well... Brought him down.

question: Oh, so that's why--?
answer: Yes! That's why he can't hold a glass.

question: Oh, I'm so ashamed.
answer: Now, Cary's had a pretty thin time. His nerves are tricky. You should never call attention to his hands.

question: Hello, Francis. Bill. Shep. Drunk again?
answer: Say, don't you know any OTHER opening remarks? It's about all we've heard from you for a year.

question: Hi! Jean! Un sidecar. Say, why don't you fellows go home and go to work?
answer: Work? What kind of work?

question: Oh, I'm so sorry. Your hands... Oh, your poor hands! Your poor, poor hands. Oh!
answer: If you aren't the WORST! First, you insult his hands and make him mad. Then you cry over them and make him self-conscious. Come on back here. Come on. Well, that's torn it. He'll never come back now.

question: Then we'll have to find him.
answer: What for?

question: To explain how sorry I am.
answer: We-ell. You don't have to get so emotional about it.

question: Who's getting emotional?
answer: You are. You're coming all apart. Here. Take a drink of this. Make you laugh and play.

question: Let's go.
answer: Hey! Where're you goin'?!

question: Oh, out.
answer: Out where?! Don't you suppose you could arrange that here?!

question: Nope. We gotta go somewheres else.
answer: Okay. Come on, Francis. We got to go somewheres else to get a drink. Hey! There he is!

question: Where?
answer: Come on! Say, what are you tryin' to do, disown us?

question: But when I was a little girl, my mother always said I had the nicest hair-ribbon.
answer: Then there's her drinking.

question: What's the matter with my drinking?
answer: You're a sissy drinker.

question: Well, maybe I can improve.
answer: Then there's her teeth. Why, one of 'em is turned sideways.

question: You mean this one?
answer: That's it.

question: Why don't you have it turned around?
answer: I don't have it turned around on account of it's a kind of help.

question: Well, in what respect does it kind of help?
answer: Well, you see, when anyone kisses me too hard, it splits my lip. And you could tell when anyone kissed me too hard on account of my lip would bleed. So now I don't let anyone kiss me -- hard.

question: Well, we'll let that pass.
answer: Where's he gone?

question: Well, when I was a little girl, I got bumped by a swing.
answer: How'd you happen to get bumped?

question: I just walked through the gate. I was only seven.
answer: Oh, poor dear. Didn't you see it?

question: I can't see very far.
answer: Did it hurt?

question: It made me dizzy all day.
answer: Well, I guess we can't hold that against her.

question: Have you got a husband or anything?
answer: No husband.

question: A mother?
answer: Mother, yes. But we haven't met in quite a long time.

question: Why not in a long time?
answer: Well, on account of my mother's name was Beulah. Now, you can't have a mother named Beulah. So I changed it to Jane. And that's how it all began.

question: Who is he, anyway?
answer: Francis used to fly with us in the 94th. The best shot in the squadron. Brought down twelve planes. Used to call him "Sudden Death." He lost interest after his teammate got killed. He's lonesome is all.

question: I like him.
answer: He carries a chiming watch on account of he's always falling asleep in the daytime.

question: What kind of chimes?
answer: Oh, Westminster, Canterbury, and Whittington.

question: Say! What do you want me to do? Tackle a horse?
answer: Sure. Go ahead. Tackle a horse.

question: All right, all right, I'll tackle a horse.
answer: Here comes one now.

question: Say, Nikki, let's ditch these drunks and go off somewhere by ourselves. These crazy fools are liable to do anything.
answer: Do you think so?

question: Since the war, they don't care what happens.
answer: And do you?

question: I'll say so. I've got more important things to think of.
answer: What more important things?

question: Well, my work.
answer: What kind of work?

question: I'm the foreign correspondent for a New York newspaper syndicate.
answer: How nice for you!

question: If you do match tricks, I'll recite.
answer: Recite what?

question: Poetry.
answer: Whose poetry?

question: My poetry.
answer: You write poetry?

question: I'll send you a photograph of my poetry.
answer: Say, I wonder if there's anything intoxicating in that.

question: Here we are. Goin' up!
answer: Who's gonna pilot this craft?

question: I'll take her off. Where's the throttle?
answer: Got your safety belts buckled?

question: Hey! Look at all the bottles! Hey! Come on in and look at Nikki's bottles! Ylang! Ylang!
answer: Hey, don't be handlin' her things. Put 'em down.

question: Chichi!
answer: Leave 'em alone.

question: Go to bed?
answer: Awww! Bed?

question: Yup, all right.
answer: So long, turtles.

question: Mmmmmm mm!
answer: Scrub hard.

question: Did anyone ever see such a back in their life? Did anyone ever HEAR of such a thing?
answer: Harder.

question: Thank you.
answer: Say, I don't think Nikki likes you.

question: Oh, no?
answer: No. What do you wanna hang around for?

question: Well, what do YOU hang around for?
answer: Me? Why, I came to bring Nikki some posies. I'll bet you didn't bring Nikki any posies.

question: Well, on account of it's raining and everything, we thought we'd go over to the Cluny and play billiards and drink beer. Went to get his hat and coat. He's going to Pre Lachaise. A cemetery. How 'bout you coming with us? You've been invited?
answer: Do you think Cary might object?

question: Well, I have an idea he'd like to be alone.
answer: Why alone?

question: Well, Cary likes to be alone. He's as brittle as a breadstick. One silly crack from you and he might break up in sections.
answer: Well, then, I don't think he should be left alone. Tell me, what's Cary doing in Paris?

question: What are we all doing in Paris?
answer: I know. But why doesn't he go home?

question: Well, he's not ready to go home. What could he do if he went home? Have people cry over his hands?
answer: Well, it seems - a pity to go on like this. He's such a sweet soul.

question: One of the best.
answer: Isn't he just sort of wasting himself?

question: On the contrary. He's trying awfully hard to get hold of himself. Now, listen. If you tag along, for heaven's sake, be careful what you say. Don't start getting sorry for him and don't cry over him. And, above all, don't make any unfortunate remarks, hear?
answer: Oh, I won't. Why, who ever heard of such a thing? Cary?! Cary? I'm coming with you. Oooh! Ooh, wait for Nikki! Wait for Nikki!

question: What are you changing your shoes for?
answer: On account of I can walk faster in red shoes.

question: On account of I can walk faster in red shoes.
answer: Perhaps we'd better stay here a while till it clears up.

question: Could we sit down here, do you suppose?
answer: I think so. Would you like something to drink?

question: What should I drink now, do you suppose?
answer: Deux picon citrons.

question: Picon citrons?
answer: Very refreshing. Make you laugh and play.

question: That's what you always promise. Cary, why does Shep Lambert go on drinking so desperately?
answer: Don't we all?

question: Not like Shep.
answer: Well, Shep has that tic under his eye, you know. Takes a lot of drinks to keep that quiet.

question: But isn't there some kind of treatment or something?
answer: Shep could never stand a long course of treatment. Drinking's the only corrective so far as he's concerned. He's found out the tic doesn't work when he's tight. So he stays tight.

question: Seems such a pity. How did he get the tic?
answer: In the war.

question: I know. But how?
answer: Well, it's not very romantic.

question: Well, don't tell me if you don't want to.
answer: Well, you see, a tic is a nervous habit.

question: Yes?
answer: Lice under his bandages.

question: Oh.
answer: He had the devil of a time. He nearly lost his mind. So you'll have to excuse him a little.

question: I'm so sorry for Shep.
answer: Well, don't let him know it.

question: Well, isn't he going home? Not ever?
answer: Not ever. Not in his dark glasses anyway.

question: Can't something be done for him?
answer: He'll have to be - reborn.

question: How's he going to end?
answer: Well, how are you going to end? How am I going to end? How is ANYONE going to end? How's your picon citron go?

question: It goes fine. But doesn't ANYTHING make any difference to you?
answer: Not now. A long time ago, perhaps, when I was a little boy.

question: Tell me, where were you little?
answer: In Minnesota. On a farm.

question: Were you happy then, Cary?
answer: I think so.

question: Tell me, what WAS there to be happy about on a farm in Minnesota?
answer: Ohhh, thorn-apple trees in blossom. The smell of burning leaves in the fall. The sound of horses' hoofs on the road. Did you ever dig up an Indian mound or uncover a nest of baby field mice? Or explore old trunks in an attic? Listen to the moaning of the telephone wires in the winter wind? See a gypsy caravan?

question: So THAT'S why you were happy. On account of apple blossoms and field mice and telephone wires and gypsy caravans and old trunks and things?
answer: That's right.

question: But aren't you going back? Not ever?
answer: Would you like another picon citron before you go? The rain is lifting.

question: No. I'm ready now. Who all is buried here?
answer: Oh, poets, painters, philosophers--

question: Cocoanut?
answer: No cocoanut. Poets, painters, philosophers, musicians. There's Chopin.

question: Oh, I practiced him.
answer: And there's Balzac. And there's Hlose and Ablard.

question: Oh, tell me about Ablise and loard.
answer: No, Nikki. Not Ablise and loard. Hlose and Ablard.

question: I'm sorry. I really didn't do it on purpose. It was on account of the picon citron. Tell me about Hlose and Ablard.
answer: Well, they're buried here in the same sepulchre side by side.

question: Why are they buried side by side?
answer: They were the world's most famous lovers. There's the tomb.

question: Tell me about the world's most famous lovers.
answer: Well, Ablard was a scholastic philosopher--

question: Whatever that is.
answer: Whatever that is. He gained a footing in a certain household as tutor to a maiden called Hlose. And employed his unlimited opportunities for the purpose of-- Well, betrayal. Not, however, unmixed with real love. He carried her off to Brittany.

question: Tell me more.
answer: Well, her uncle was furious. He blamed Ablard for the whole thing. He conceived a terrible revenge.

question: I'm afraid for Ablard.
answer: He broke into Ablard's apartment one night and perpetrated upon him the most brutal punishment.

question: Oh, dear.
answer: The lovers were forced to live their lives apart. But when they died, they were buried here side by side. There's a story that little heart- shaped stones are supposed to grow around the tomb.

question: Heart-shaped stones?
answer: And lovers come and find them and exchange them with each other. And, so long as you keep the stone from the tomb of Hlose and Ablard, no harm can come to your true love.

question: How perfectly beautiful.
answer: Isn't that a quaint legend?

question: Do you think I might find a heart- shaped stone? You help me, Cary.
answer: All right, Nikki. Only we have to leave soon. They close up the place.

question: Just as soon as we find our stones. I found one! Where's yours? And, now, you take mine. And I'll take yours. Isn't that the way the story goes?
answer: That's right, Nikki.

question: And, now, no harm can come to our true love.
answer: And, now, we'll have to go.

question: You were so nice to let me come with you. I spoiled your whole day. You were going to do something else, weren't you?
answer: Doesn't matter.

question: Well, what was it, Cary? Why did you come here today?
answer: To pay my respects to an old comrade.

question: Oh. And you wanted to be alone. I'm sorry. Oh, I'm so sorry. Don't pay any attention to me, Cary. I can't help it. You MAKE me cry. Oh, don't look so troubled, Cary. I'm all right. I just want to cry for a minute. On account of you're so nice. You're so clean, Cary. And your teeth are so white. You're so civilized. You don't care about anything any more, nor anybody. Nothing makes any difference to you. Nothing can touch you. Why, you're lost. You're ALL lost. You and Shep and the rest of you. Oh, I want to do something for you. I want to help you. Let me wash your bracelet, Cary. Why, see? The silver's all tarnished. The silver's all tarnished. I'll take it with me and scrub it when I get home. I'll polish it with my nail-brush.
answer: It's getting dark.

question: Well ... Anyway, we found a name for my turtles!
answer: Hlose and Ablard? A name for your turtles? So that's what you were looking for. I might have known how it would end.

question: Hi, Nik.
answer: Hello.

question: Cary's in a state. Says he's going away. Can't stand it any longer and all that sort of thing. What happened between you two, anyway?
answer: Cary seemed so sad and everything -- on account of I'd taken up his whole afternoon. So little Nikki said, all merry and bright, "Well, anyway, we'd found a name for my turtles."

question: A name for the turtles? That's funny! Name for the turtles! That's so funny, all right! Why do you always HAVE to be funny at the wrong time? Didn't I tell you Cary was brittle? How did he respond to THAT line?
answer: Pulled down the iron curtain. Did he say he was going away?

question: Yup. Gotta get away from it all.
answer: Then, you've got to go to him right now! And explain that I didn't mean it! Tell him how it was and everything!

question: Listen--
answer: No, go on. You go right now before it's too late!

question: But Nikki--!
answer: You go right straight to Cary.

question: Now, listen, Cary, you don't have to behave like an old Easter egg. You're breaking Nikki's heart. She doesn't know any better.
answer: She doesn't know any better? Well, whether she does or not, I'm going a long ways away from Nikki. Nikki and her turtles.

question: Whew! You sure are in an uproar. What YOU need is a drink!
answer: I need more than a drink. I need a lot of geography between me and that girl.

question: Where do you want to go?
answer: Anywheres. So long as it's a long way from Nikki. You know -- that girl does things to me. I've got to get away.

question: Well, I wonder what's happening in Portugal tonight.
answer: Say ... I wonder what IS happening in Portugal tonight.

question: Can you imagine that ungrateful old trollop? She wouldn't let them help her undress.
answer: Can't understand it at all.

question: You know, she's not very pretty. But when she was a little girl, her mother always said she had the nicest hair-ribbons.
answer: Indeed?

question: She got one tooth turned around, she can't see very far, and she's ALWAYS speaking out of turn. Otherwise, she's a mighty fine piece of architecture.
answer: Mm, seems to need a few repairs.

question: I did SO see an Assyrian Queen.
answer: In whose green hat?

question: In the Metropolitan Museum's green hat, that's whose green hat.
answer: Hold on there! Where you goin'?

question: I have to sprinkle the turtles, see?
answer: Sprinkle the turtles?

question: Sure. Cool 'em off.
answer: Hm?

question: Turtles get feverish on trains.
answer: Ahh! Uh huh.

question: What's that?
answer: Hm?

question: Wake up, ya big sissy. Here, drink this. It'll make you laugh and play like any old thing.
answer: Say, Cary, what day is this?

question: It's Wednesday.
answer: Wednesday? Wednesday what?

question: The twentieth.
answer: What month, I mean?

question: You mean to say you don't know what month this is?
answer: I knew once but I forgot.

question: Well, it's June. The merry month of June.
answer: June? Say, maybe I better get up. What town are we in?

question: You're in Lisbon, Portugal.
answer: Lisbon. That's where I thought it was. I just wanted to check up is all.

question: Say, what's the matter with you, Shep? Don't you really know where you are or what day it is?
answer: I kind of lose track of things.

question: Say, this is getting serious.
answer: Serious? Is anything serious any more?

question: Well, it's serious when you don't know where you're at. What's gonna become of you?
answer: Oh, I'll be all right when I've had a couple of drinks. Say, what town did you say this was?

question: I just told you, Lisbon. Come on, now, pull yourself together, Shep. We gotta get organized for the bull-fight.
answer: Bull-fight? Are we going to a bull-fight?

question: Sure. A Portuguese bull-fight.
answer: Is that guy Frink coming along?

question: 'Fraid so.
answer: Gee, isn't there any way we can get rid of that guy?

question: Somebody'll have to shoot him.
answer: Not a bad idea at that.

question: I don't like beer.
answer: Make you leap like a tuna.

question: Don't wanna leap like a tuna.
answer: Make you bark like a fox.

question: Don't wanna bark like a fox.
answer: Make you laugh and play.

question: That's what I wanna do! Laugh and play!
answer: Hey! Vermouth!

question: Hey! Vermouth!
answer: Well, men, fire and fall back! Hey! What's the idea? Well, I hope I don't catch a cold in my left ear.

question: Hey, drink your drinks! We'll miss the parade!
answer: Well! My old pal!

question: Oh, seor, no, no, no -- you must not keep the hat. You must put a little present in it and return it to the matador after the fight.
answer: What kind of present?

question: Well, eh - a little jewelry. Something you have like the chain or the watch or the - the - the cigarette case or the cuff links or - or the--
answer: Vanilla?

question: Yes! Vanilla!
answer: Look! Here he comes!

question: Nice work! Good work.
answer: What's so good about it?

question: He works close to the bull.
answer: Is that so dangerous?

question: Nice work, Tony! Nice work, Joe!
answer: Bill! Come back here! Bill! Take it easy! Take it easy!

question: Cary? I slipped.
answer: Too bad. You were doing fine.

question: Wasn't I, though? Heh. It's a cinch. Bull-fighting? Just as easy-- Hey, Doc?! Be careful. What are you doing? You know why I slipped, Cary?
answer: No, Bill. Why?

question: Cary, let's see you shoot something.
answer: Look out, ball!

question: What'd YOU aim at?
answer: Well, let's see you shoot something. Oh, no, no, no, Nikki.

question: How do you hold it still?
answer: Listen, Nikki, on your right shoulder. Now, put your hand out there and hold up-- No, don't cover up the site. No, no, no, that's right. Now just hold it evenly-- You can do better than that. Show him up.

question: Listen, Nikki, on your right shoulder. Now, put your hand out there and hold up-- No, don't cover up the site. No, no, no, that's right. Now just hold it evenly-- You can do better than that. Show him up.
answer: What are you waving at, Nikki?

question: Look out! Why, you fool. Don't you know better than that?
answer: What's the idea?

question: Pointing a loaded gun at Nikki?
answer: Take your hands off me.

question: Put down that gun!
answer: Let go of my wrist!

question: Put down that gun!
answer: Listen, you keep your hands off me! I've had enough from you! You try any more of your rough stuff on me--!

question: Oh, so that's how it is. I thought we taught you how to behave.
answer: You taught ME how to behave?! Listen, you'd better behave now or you'll get hurt!

question: I don't think so. I'll give you three to put down that gun. It'll be just too bad if you don't.
answer: Too bad for who?!

question: One ...
answer: Keep away from me! I'll shoot, I tell ya! I'll shoot!

question: Two ...
answer: I'll shoot! I'll shoot!

question: Don't worry about, Francis. He'll take care of himself. Let's get out of here. Let's walk.
answer: No. Don't want to walk. Let's take a cab.

question: Did you see the way Francis poured lead into that fellow?
answer: Fast work.

question: Fast? Chain lightning!
answer: Nice shooting.

question: Those slugs went right past my ear. If I'd've moved an inch, I would've caught one of them myself.
answer: "Sudden Death," all right.

question: What's the matter with you, Shep? I've never known you so quiet before.
answer: That's right. I am kind of quiet.

question: That's right. I am kind of quiet.
answer: Not smoking?

question: No.
answer: Your lighter working?

question: Good ol', Nikki -- never has any matches.
answer: No.

question: Sure you want a light?
answer: That's what I want, a light. Shep. Shep!

question: Shep, why didn't you say you were hurt?
answer: Good old Cary. Sweet Nikki. You may not believe it but this is the best thing that ever happened to me.

question: Oh, Shep, Shep, don't say that. You'll be all right. We'll get you to a hospital.
answer: No, no, Cary. Don't rush me anywheres. Let's sit here for a while. The-- Hurts, the jolting.

question: Stop! Stop!
answer: That's better. You know, Cary, I feel - just like we're falling -- long time ago. Do you remember? Spinning ... spinning ... spinning. Only you brought me down safe. Oh, Cary. Good old Cary. Best flyer in the service.
